titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Bob Johnson Papers, 1949-2003 CTC.2014.03
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Meaghan Alston.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-09-25T16:02-0400

did.abstract: The Bob Johnson Papers contain paper based, photographic, and audio-visual materials related to the Brooklyn born, Pittsburgh-based, dancer/choreographer, actor and director. Johnson founded the Pittsburgh Black Theatre Dance Ensemble and served as a dance and drama lecturer at the University of Pittsburgh. Additionally, Robert Johnson toured internationally as a dancer and participated in a number of local, Broadway, and Off-Broadway productions as an actor, choreographer, and director.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Bob Johnson Papers are arranged into the following series:
V. Pittsburgh Black Theatre Dance Ensemble, 1970-1985
VI. Teaching at the University of Pittsburgh, 1969-1986
VII. Black Arts Movement Scripts and Ephemera, 1966-1990

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Robert “Bob” Johnson was born on March 31, 1938 in Brooklyn, New York, to Viola Sutton and Fredrick Johnson. He received his foundational dance training at the New York Metropolitan High School of the Performing Arts (now LaGuardia High School of Music & Art and Performing Arts). Johnson began his professional career in 1960 as a member of the Eleo Pomare and Raymond Sawyer Dance Company. During this time, he continued his formal study of dance at a number of New York-based studios. On scholarships, Johnson studied dance composition, Hattian and Afro-Caribbean under Jean-Léon Destiné at the New Dance Group Studio, the Lector Horton Technique at the Clark Center of the Performing Arts, and the Katherine Dunham Technique under Ms. Dunham herself.

In 1965, Johnson traveled to Paris as part of Katherine Dunham’s last professional company and took part in the French movie musical Deux Anges Sont Venus and the film adaptation of Léopold Sédar Senghor’s Chaka. Upon returning to the United States in 1966, Mr. Johnson took dance instructor positions in Washington, D.C. and New York City. In this same year he made his acting debut as the lead in Kelly Marie Berry’s dance drama, Black Happenin’. In 1967, Bob Johnson appeared in the N.Y. Shakespeare Festival original production of Hair. This was quickly followed by a dramatic role in Ed Bullins’ Off-Broadway production, Goin’ a Buffallo. Between 1968 and 1969 he returned to his dance background with stints with the Harlem Cultural Council’s Dancemobile.

In 1969, Bob Johnson relocated to Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, to serve as a dance consultant for Project Self Esteem, a collaboration between local universities and youth groups. Members of the University of Pittsburgh’s Black Studies Department took notice of Johnson in this role and offered him a position teaching both dance and drama in the department starting in the 1970-1971 school year. He accepted the post and remained in the department until his death in 1986. His courses included Afro American Dance I and II and Kuumba Theatre Workshop, later renamed Creativity Workshop. It was also in Pittsburgh where he met and married his wife, the former Stephanie Cooper.

In 1970, Bob Johnson founded the Pittsburgh Black Theatre Dance Ensemble which aimed to shed light on the breadth of culture in the African Diaspora to bring attention to issues facing the community through dance. Johnson served as artistic director of the company for a number of years during which time he choreographed signature works such as Free Spirit Song, Ritual of Damballah, Ego Trippin’ and American Fruit with African Roots. Outside of the university and the dance company he founded, Mr. Johnson continued to work professionally as a dancer, choreographer, actor and director. During the summer months, Johnson toured nationally and internationally as a Dancer with Sun Ra and His Arkestra, performing in such places as Nigeria, Italy, France, and the Netherlands. As a choreographer, he crafted dance numbers for local productions such as the musical Liberty Avenue, and Off-Broadway Plays including Who Loves the Dancer by Rob Penny and How do you Spell Watergait by James Durrah. He continued to pursue local stage work and made his film debut in the John Russo horror film Midnight. Johnson would also go on to direct theater, notably the first staged production of August Wilson’s Jitney in 1982.
Bob Johnson passed away due to heart failure on July 6, 1986.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Bob Johnson Papers date from Johnson's late teens and early twenties in 1950s and 1960s (New York City) through his death in Pittsburgh in 1986. The collection is comprised of personal and professional letters, writings, contracts, scripts, theatre ephemera, and choreographic and artistic notes/illustrations. Further, the Johnson Papers contain photographic and A/V items, press clippings, material related to the Pittsburgh Black Theatre Dance Ensemble, material related to his tenure as a lecturer at the University of Pittsburgh, and the papers of his widow, the late Stephanie Cooper Johnson. The collection is broken into eight series and a number of subseries and sections. For the most part, each subseries' or section's folders are listed in chronological order.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Johnson Estate: Marimba Johnson Bright (daughter) and Samba Johnson (son) in December 2014.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Bob Johnson Papers, 1949-2003, CTC.2014.03, Curtis Theatre Collection, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Meaghan Alston and Catherine Peebles between September 2015 and August 2016.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The Ford E. and Harriet R. Curtis Theatre Collection of Pittsburgh Performing Arts Information Files, CTC.Infofiles.Pgh, Curtis Theatre Collection, Archives & Special Collections Department, University of Pittsburgh Library System

accessrestrict.head: Access and Use
accessrestrict.p: In compliance with FERPA regulations, the following material has restricted access: Series VI: Teaching at the University of Pittsburgh: Subseries 3: Classes: Section: Student Work. To access material in this series the researcher must agree to sign a confidentiality agreement provided by Archives & Special Collections. All remaining portions of the collection are free of restrictions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains personal material related to Bob Johnson over the course of his life. Items in the series include a selection of awards and personal effects from his youth and artistic career, personal correspondence and topical material related to racial justice and the arts. This series also contains items related to Mr. Johnson’s 1986 death and memorial services, and over 30 years of personal photographs.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Stephanie Cooper Johnson was born November 10, 1948 in McKeesport, Pennsylvania, to Samuel and Ernestine Davis Cooper. Mrs. Johnson graduated from McKeesport High School and later went on to attend the University of Pittsburgh. At Pitt she earned both her B.S. and Masters of Library and Information Science. She then worked for many years as the children’s librarian at both the Homewood and Wilkinsburg libraries.

Mrs. Johnson was deeply involved in her community and active in a number of organizations. She served as a committee member of Pittsburgh Ward 4, an officer with the University of Pittsburgh African American Alumni Council, member of the Alumnae Association, and Afro-American History Society. Mrs. Johnson’s deepest and most sustained involvement was with the Pittsburgh Black Theatre Dance Ensemble, founded by her late husband Bob Johnson. Stephanie Johnson was instrumental in orchestrating the company’s revival in the early 2000s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Items in this series relate to activities in Stephanie Johnson’s community work and personal life, her work with the Pittsburgh Black Theatre Dance Ensemble and its revival, as well as her time as an officer with the University of Pittsburgh’s African American Alumni Council

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series is made up of a number of Bob Johnson's personal journals and notebooks. They contain handwritten entries on numerous topics including poetry, dance, teaching, acting, politics, and daily observations. Taken as a whole, they serve as a unique insight into the creative mind of Mr. Johnson. These journals and notebooks were rarely dated or titled. The titles and arrangement were impossed by the archivists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series documents professional activities in Mr. Johnson's career over a 30 year period between 1955 and 1985. The first subseries relates to professional correspondence, while all remaining subseries contain manuscript, photographs and audiovisual material related to specific artistic roles inhabited by Bob Johnson during his career including dancer, choreographer, actor, director, and writer. Some examples of material in this series include ephemera and photographs from throughout his career including some of Mr. Johnson’s earliest professional dance and instructor events as well as his time in the company for Hair. Also included are journals and correspondence from his time in Paris with the Dunham Company, scripts for plays that he choreographed like Liberty Avenue, acted in like Day of the Picnic, or directed like August Wilson’s Jitney! The series also contains a number of poems and an autobiographical play entitled Plunk’s Theme.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Johnson directed the world premiere production of August Wilson's Jitney in October and November, 1982. It was performed at the Fine Line Cultural Center in Oakland as a part of the Allegheny Repertory Theatre's 1982/1983 season. The production's cast was composed of local actors and community leaders, including Sala Udin. Photographs in this series include actors Claude Purdy as Becker, Ronald Pitts as Fielding, Milton Thompson as Turnbo, Gwendolyn Perry as Rena, Buck Price as The Man, and Monte Russell as Youngblood. There is also one folder of photographs from the 1996 production of Jitney at the Pittsburgh Public Theater.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Pittsburgh Black Theatre Dance series has manuscript, photographic, and audiovisual items pertaining to the history of the arts company founded by Bob Johnson in 1970. The company’s goal was to explore and uplift the people of the Black Diaspora through the performing arts. Johnson served as artistic director of the company for many years with the core leadership team and faculty that included, Linda F. Wharton, who later went on to become artistic director of the company, Oliver Byrd, Linda Herring, Sherry Hoard, Bill Johnson, Maliki Roberts and Malaya Rucker. The series provides general information on the company as a whole as well as its subsidiary group the Afro American Dance Center and acting arm Theatre Urge. Specific materials include company by-laws and board meeting minutes, correspondence, ephemera, press, photographs and audiovisual material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Items in this series relate to Mr. Johnson’s 16-year tenure as in instructor in the University of Pittsburgh’s Department of Africana Studies, known then as Black Studies. Materials include correspondence, departmental items, and teaching related content like course descriptions and syllabi, readings, and a small sample of student work. This material helps offer insight into Johnson’s teaching methods.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The material in this series contains theatre scripts, performing arts newsletters, and dance company ephemera of artists and performers of the Black Arts Movement. These artists and performers were from both Pittsburgh and elsewhere in the United States. The series has scripts from Amiri Baraka such as A Black Mass and Columbia Gem of the Ocean, Rob Penny’s, Centre Avenue: A Trip and Dance of the Blues Dead, several plays by William F. Mayfield, and August Wilson’s The Coldest Day of the Year. There are also a number of scripts by local playwrights such as William F. Mayfield’s Black Sci- Fi Saga. The series also contains newsletters from The Black Theatre Alliance and Dance Herald, and The Feet, as well as ephemera from the Chuck Davis, Author Hall, and Eleo Pomare dance companies among others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries of scripts is arranged alphabetically by the author's last name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The contents list for the Audio/Visual Recordings series of this collection is still in-process. There are over 200 audio recordings on cassettes and reels. There are also over 100 film and video recordings on 16mm film, videotape on reel, VHS, and U-Matic cassettes. Several recordings have been reformatted and are available for use. Researchers should contact the Archives & Special Collections staff about other recordings in the collection and how to access them.
